Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: We are provided with a normative process description and an event log. We need to list cases that deviate from intended process flow as well as explanation of why these deviations violate the normative rules. Lets read prompt carefully: The text describes a normative process for handling orders. It says: the general idea is that an order, once received, should be handled in accordance with availability. Process always begins with Receive order. After receiving, next logical step is to check inventory (Check inventory). Then if inventory is sufficient, sequence: Authorize payment, Package items, Ship order, Close order. If insufficient then branch into cancellation scenario: after checking inventory, process directly proceeds to Cancel order, and then Close order.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Normative description states the constraints: - Authorize payment should occur after Check inventory and before packaging. - Package items should only occur after authorization and before shipping. - Ship order should occur after packaging and never after cancellation. - Close order is final activity in all scenarios. Any deviation from these principles (like shipping after cancellation, authorizing payment before check, or packaging items before authorization) are considered violation.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Given event log: Case 1: Timestamps: 09:00 Receive order 10:00 Check inventory 11:00 Authorize payment 12:00 Package items 13:00 Ship order 14:00 Close order This case is exactly matching intended sequence for sufficient inventory (Receive, check, authorize, package, ship, close). So its correct.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2: Timestamps: 09:00 Receive order, 09:30 Check inventory, 10:00 Package items, 10:30 Authorize payment, 11:00 Ship order, 11:30 Close order. Here we see violation: Package items is executed before Authorize Payment. According to normative process, Authorization should occur after check inventory and before packaging. So in case 2, the sequence is wrong because its doing package items then authorize payment. This violates Authorize payment rule and ordering of packaging.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Case 3: Timestamps: 09:00 Receive order, 09:20 Check inventory, 09:40 Authorize payment, 10:00 Cancel order, 10:30 Ship order, 11:00 Close order. Check process for cancellation scenario. The description says if inventory insufficient, after check inventory, the process should directly proceed to Cancel order (so no authorization payment is allowed in cancellation branch). But here case 3 has both Authorize Payment and then Cancel Order. Also normative text says Ship order should never occur after a cancellation. In this event log, after cancelling, theres shipping. So two violations: In case of cancellation scenario, process should skip packaging or shipping if inventory insufficient; but instead we see authorizing payment and shipping after cancellation, which violates the intended process. Wait double-check description: if the inventory check reveals that there is not enough stock to fulfill the order, the process must branch into a cancellation scenario. In such a case, after checking inventory, the process should directly proceed to Cancel order. Once an order is canceled, it would be illogical to continue with activities intended for fulfillment (such as packaging or shipping) ... So in Case 3, after receiving and check inventory, then authorize payment is performed and then cancel order. The text says that if insufficient stock then branch into cancellation scenario: meaning that there should not be Authorize Payment at all because its not needed when youre cancelling the order. And also, shipping should never occur after cancellation. But here, after cancellation, we see Ship order. So violation.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 4: Timestamps: 09:00 Receive order, 09:10 Check inventory, 09:20 Cancel order, 09:50 Close order. This is valid for cancellation scenario as described: After checking inventory, directly cancel order and then close order. It does not include Authorize Payment or packaging or shipping which are not allowed in cancellation branch.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 5: Timestamps: 09:00 Receive order, 10:00 Check inventory, 10:30 Authorize payment, 11:00 Ship order, 11:30 Close order. We see violation: In this case, Package items is missing. But what does the process description say? It says if inventory is sufficient, then sequence should be: after confirming inventory, proceed with authorization of payment (ensuring that customers payment method valid), once payment authorized, package items then ship order and close order. So in case 5, packaging step is missing. Is that a violation as per the text? The normative description says Once payment is authorized, the items should be prepared for shipmentthis is commonly referred to as Package items. And it further states: only after items have been properly packaged is it appropriate to proceed with Ship order. So in case 5, missing package items means that shipping order was executed without packaging. Therefore, violation. But wait, check carefully: The text says: The process always begins with the Receive order activity. After an order is received, the next logical step is to check inventory. If the inventory is found to be sufficient, then normal progression should continue as follows: after confirming inventory, process includes authorization of payment ensuring that customers payment method is valid and approved. Once payment is authorized, items should be prepared for shipmentthis is commonly referred to as Package items. Only after packaging is it appropriate to proceed with Ship order. And also Close order final step. So case 5 missing package items violates the normative process, because shipping was done without packaging.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Thus, summary: Case violations: - Case 2: Violates the sequence ordering by executing Package items before Authorize payment. So violation of rule that payment authorization should occur after check inventory and before packaging. - Case 3: Has multiple deviations: it authorizes payment in a cancellation branch; then shipping order is performed after cancellation, which violates rules that shipping should never follow cancellation. - Case 5: Violates the sequence by skipping the Package items step after payment authorization. Case 1 and case 4 are correct sequences as per normative process. So answer: Violations: Case 2: The ordering of steps is wrong. Instead of doing Authorize Payment followed by Package Items, it does Package Items first, then Authorize Payment. This violates the requirement that Authorize payment must occur before packaging. Case 3: The case shows a cancellation scenario where inventory check leads to cancellation; however, additional activities (Authorize Payment and Ship Order) occur after cancellation which are not allowed in the normative process for insufficient inventory orders. Case 5: Missing mandatory Package Items step. Shipping occurred without having been preceded by proper packaging.
